7.text: you might be able to put down roots in the area you want to live.

11.text: But for many of us in the UK, finding a home we can afford is becoming more difficult.

15.text: Prices in the south in particular are out of control,

18.text: rising further and further beyond our pay.

21.text: Rental markets are a rip off and insecure.

25.text:
And across the country social
housing is becoming a thing of the past.

28.text: It's easy to feel like the game is rigged.

33.text: But who are we actually playing against?

35.text:
Investors are pouring money into property,
with estate agents cashing in.

40.text: And landlords are securing their future with our rents.

44.text: But deeper than that, the REAL issue lies with our systems.

51.text: Most people can't afford to buy a home alone, so they need to borrow.

55.text: Banks are happy about this because mortgages are lower risk than other kinds of loans.

59.text: If it all goes wrong, the bank gets the house.

64.text: The more mortgages the banks give out, the more people can afford a home.

67.text: But the more borrowed money goes into housing, the more prices rise

70.text: And the more prices rise, the more people need big mortgages to afford those homes.

77.text: And what about those who just can't afford it?

79.text: The government HELPS them to buy, with a loan to get a loan, pushing prices up further.

85.text: As a few get a leg up on to the ladder, the ladder is pushed further out of reach for the rest.

93.text: But there's a whole other system at play in the housing crisis.

98.text: but the recent rise in house prices has in fact mostly come from increasing land prices.

103.text: Why is land worth so much?

106.text: Well, because it's tax free and there's only so much of it.

109.text: So you can make a profit just by holding on to it.

112.text: Which means, silly as it sounds, when big developers want to make

115.text:
money, it makes sense to build FEWER
houses to keep land and property prices in

121.text: So, developers keep prices high, and more people need mortgages.

131.text: Becuase, as we've already seen, if the growth of mortgage lending

134.text: out-paces the supply of new homes, prices will just keep rising.

140.text: It's in all the banks, land and property owners and private developers INTERESTS to keep pumping prices up.

146.text: That's just the way our systems are set up.

150.text: And when prices rise so far above incomes

152.text: that people fail to meet their mortgage payments, the bubble bursts

156.text: and the economy crashes, just like we've seen before.

164.text: We can all make a difference by demanding the following:

167.text: a separation of the cost of land from that of a home

173.text: a boost in options for not-for-profit and low-debt homes

178.text: an affordable and more secure private rented sector

182.text: and a diverse banking system that builds the economy, not bubbles.

188.text: We don't have to play by these rules.
